anchor.surface_text: The mandatory character of s. 6 is indicated by the language employed in that section and the phraseology of all the sections following, i.e., 7 to 12, employing the words the tax shall be payable under the head in respect of the different and distinct heads of income, profits and gains, salaries Interest on securities , and property , business etc. is indicative of the intention of the legislature making the various heads of income, profits and gains mutually exclusive.

It being a specific head of chargeability of tax, income from interest on securities whether held as a trading asset or capital asset would have to be taxed under s. 8 and number under s. 10 of the Act.

He further companytends that the scheme of s. 24 1  and  2  shows that profits and gains must be arising under s. 10 and number under any other section because the expression used is profits or gains which goes with business under s. 10 and cannot have reference to income, profits and gains arising from interest on securities which are under s. 8 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: No finding if securities part of same business; no opinion expressed

holdings.text: Interest on securities, whether held as trading assets or capital assets, must be taxed under section 8 and not under section 10 of the Income Tax Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Heads of income under s.6 are mutually exclusive and specific; s.8 covers all interest on securities regardless of purpose or holder; supported by statutory scheme, return form, amendments, and precedents like Salisbury House.

holdings.text: The various heads of income under sections 6 to 12 are mutually exclusive; income falling under one specific head cannot be taxed under another.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory language in ss.6-12 uses 'shall be payable under the head'; classification by source; precedents confirm exclusivity (Salisbury, Butler, Kothari); no overlap allows shifting heads.

holdings.text: Sections 3 and 4 are the charging sections; sections 7-12 are for computation of total income under specific heads.

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court in Chatturam and others Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar 3 said The liability to pay the tax is founded on ss. 3 and 4 of the Income-tax Act which are the charging sections. The judgment of the Privy Council in Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax 4 also shows s. 3 to be the charging section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes older Privy Council view in Probhat Chandra where ss.3/4 worded differently; follows Federal Court and Privy Council precedents identifying ss.3/4 as charging.

holdings.text: No option for assessee to choose head of income or for Revenue to shift; specific head governs.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Heads not overlapping or one general/specific over other; both s.8 and s.10 specific; rejects Bosotto Bros. option where multiple heads apply; principle generalia specialibus inapplicable.

holdings.text: Whether loss under s.24(2) can be set off against interest on securities assuming separate heads not decided, due to absence of finding that securities holding part of same business.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Point open as question wide; but no factual finding on 'same business' unlike Punjab Co-op; unnecessary as heads separate precludes set-off on primary ground.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ahmuty company Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: Reference is in this connection made to Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ahmuty company Ltd.  1  where it was held by the High Court of Bombay that dividend income received by a dealer in shares is chargeable under s. 10 and number under s. 12 of the Act. It is thus companytended that in order to preserve the unity and oneness of the business of the assessee and to maintain the unity of its business income the applicability of s. 8 should be circumscribed to interest on securities when they are -not trading assets of the assessee.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ahmuty & Co. Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: dividend income received by a dealer in shares is chargeable under s. 10 and not under s. 12 of the Act

precedents.citation: Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor  1

anchor.surface_text: The argument raised by companynsel for the Revenue is that according to the decision of the Privy Council in Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor  1  s. 6 is the charging section and that the words of ss. 7 to 12 show that the various heads of income are mutually exclusive and items which specifically fall under these various heads have to be charged under only that head and would fall under one of these several but appropriately specific sections.

precedents.case_name: Probhat Chandra Barua v. King Emperor

anchor.surface_text: It is true that the Privy Council in Probhat Chandra Barua v. The King Emperor  supra  did point out that s. 6 was a charging section, but this was because ss. 3 and 4 were then differently worded as pointed out by Kania, J., in B.M. Kamdar, In re  2   at p. 43 and by Chagla, J., in the, same case at p. 57.

precedents.cited_proposition: ss. 3 and 4 were then differently worded

precedents.citation: Chatturam and others Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar 3

anchor.surface_text: The Federal Court in Chatturam and others Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar 3  said The liability to pay the tax is founded on ss. 3 and 4 of the Income-tax Act which are the charging sections.

precedents.case_name: Chatturam v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bihar
precedents.cited_proposition: liability to pay tax founded on ss. 3 and 4 which are charging sections

precedents.citation: Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  4

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Privy Council in Wallace Brothers Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax  4  also shows s. 3 to be the charging section.

precedents.case_name: Wallace Brothers & Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax

anchor.surface_text: In the words of Viscount Dunedin in Salisbury House Estate v. Fry 1  Now, the cardinal companysideration in my judgment is that the income tax is only one tax, a tax on the income of the person whom it is sought to assess, and that the different schedules are modes in which the Statute directs this to be levied .

precedents.case_name: Salisbury House Estate Ltd. v. Fry
precedents.cited_proposition: different schedules are modes for levying one tax; must apply correct schedule based on source
precedents.cited_holding: income tax is one tax; schedules mutually exclusive

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Chunilal Mehta l

anchor.surface_text: Sir George Rankin in Commissioner of Income Tax v. Chunilal Mehta l  said The effect of s. 6 is to classify profits and gains, under different heads for the purpose of providing for each appropriate rules for companyputing the amount its language is shall be chargeable in the manner hereinafter appearing.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Chunilal Mehta
precedents.cited_proposition: s. 6 classifies income into mutually exclusive heads; business distinct from investment
precedents.cited_holding: heads of income are mutually exclusive

precedents.citation: Salisbury House Estate Ltd. v. Fry  1

anchor.surface_text: Decided cases all support the companytention of companynsel for the Revenue that the various heads of income enumerated in s. 6 of the Act and more particularly dealt with in ss. 7 to 12 are exclusive heads and if an item of income falls under one of these heads then it has to be treated for the purpose of income tax under that head and numberother. In Salisbury House Estate Ltd. v. Fry  1  the assessee was a limited companypany which was formed for the express purpose of acquiring Salisbury House and utilising it.

precedents.case_name: Salisbury House Estate Ltd. v. Fry
precedents.cited_proposition: schedules mutually exclusive; income from property under Sch A not Sch D even if trading
precedents.cited_holding: if income falls under one schedule, cannot be assessed under another

precedents.citation: Butler v. The Mortgage Company of Egypt Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: In Butler v. The Mortgage Company of Egypt Ltd.  1 , a British companypany companytrolled in Egypt was carrying on business of lending money on mortgage of land in Egypt or on the security of debentures by mortgage of land.

precedents.case_name: Butler v. Mortgage Company of Egypt Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: interest on securities taxed under specific provision even if part of business
precedents.cited_holding: banker cannot treat interest on govt securities as business income

precedents.citation: Thompson v. The Trust and Loan Company of Canada  1

anchor.surface_text: in Thompson v. The Trust and Loan Company of Canada  1 , the respondent companypany carried on business as a loan and finance companypany. During the material years the companypany bought treasury bonds cum-coupons and on the same day sold bonds of the same numberinal value retaining the companypons and received on encashment a half years interest under deduction of income tax.

precedents.case_name: Thompson v. Trust and Loan Company of Canada
precedents.cited_proposition: interest taxed under Sch C cannot be included in Sch D computation
precedents.cited_holding: cannot treat transaction under different schedule

precedents.citation: The Commercial Properties Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: The Commercial Properties Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Bengal 1  was a case of a registered companypany whose sole object was to acquire lands,, build houses and let them to tenants, the sole business of the companypany being the management and companylection of rents from the properties.

precedents.case_name: Commercial Properties Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: income from property under s9 not business under s10 even if company owns for that purpose
precedents.cited_holding: income derived from property is specific category

precedents.citation: H. C. Kothari v, Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: The applicability of s. 8 directly arose and was discussed in H. C. Kothari v, Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 . The assessees in that case had several sources of income, one of which was interest on securities.

precedents.case_name: H.C. Kothari v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: s.8 is separate head; cannot change head under which income charged
precedents.cited_holding: if chargeable under s.8, cannot tax under different head

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Incometax v. Bosotto Bros.  2

anchor.surface_text: It was also pointed out in this judgment following Commissioner of Incometax v. Bosotto Bros.  2  that if income falls under more than one head the assessee has the option to choose the head which makes the burden on his shoulders lighter.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Bosotto Bros.
precedents.cited_proposition: if income falls under more than one head, assessee can choose lighter burden head

precedents.citation: Mangalagiri Sri Umamaheshwara Gin and Rice Factory Ltd. Guntur Merchants Gin and Rice Factory Ltd.  3

anchor.surface_text: The following two cases were relied upon by the assessee- Mangalagiri Sri Umamaheshwara Gin and Rice Factory Ltd. Guntur Merchants Gin and Rice Factory Ltd.  3  where a limited companypany incorporated for the purpose of milling rice leased out the buildings, plant, machinery etc., to another companypany for a fixed annual rent.

precedents.case_name: Mangalagiri Sri Umamaheshwara Gin and Rice Factory Ltd. v. Guntur Merchants Gin and Rice Factory Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: letting out rice mill for fixed rent is business entitled to depreciation

anchor.surface_text: The other case is Sadhucharan Roy Chowdhry, In re  1  the facts of which were similar to the facts of Mangalagiri Sri Umamaheshwara Gin and Rice Factory Ltd. v. Guntur Merchants Gin and Rice Factory Ltd.  supra .

precedents.cited_proposition: letting jute press at rent is business, depreciation allowed

anchor.surface_text: The appellants companytention that looking at the real nature and character of the source of income arising from interest on securities in the case of the present assessee, the Bank, s. 10 of the Act would apply and number s. 8 can receive numbersupport from the decision in Davies v. Braithwaite  2 .

precedents.cited_proposition: professional engagements of actress fall under one head

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Messrs. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.  1

anchor.surface_text: The case is similar to the one in Commissioner of Income-tax v. Messrs. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.  1 . The question framed by the Tribunal is a general one and what is to be determined is whether the loss of the previous year can be set off against the income of the assessment year within the provisions of s. 24 2  of the Act.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Ogale Glass Works Ltd.
precedents.cited_proposition: new point can be raised if covered by question referred

precedents.citation: Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. The, Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab 1

anchor.surface_text: He refers to s. 277 F of the Indian Companies Act and relies on the Privy Council decision in Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. The, Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab 1  in which it was pointed out that in the ordinary case of a bank the business companysists in its essence of dealing with money and credit.

precedents.case_name: Punjab Co-operative Bank Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Punjab
precedents.cited_proposition: bank's business is dealing in money and credit; realising securities part of banking

justification_sets.label: Mutually Exclusive Heads of Income support
